Package com.google.mu.util.stream

Class Walker<T>

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.google.mu.util.stream.Walker<T>
  • public final class Walker<T>
extends java.lang.Object
    Implements generic graph and tree traversal algorithms (pre-order, post-order and breadth-first) as lazily evaluated streams, allowing infinite-size graphs.

    None of these streams are safe to run in parallel.

    Since:
    3.9

    • Method Detail

      • detectCycle

        public static <T> java.util.Optional<java.util.stream.Stream<T>> detectCycle​(T startNode,
                                                                             java.util.function.Function<? super T,​? extends java.util.stream.Stream<? extends T>> findSuccessors)
        Detects whether the graph structure as observed by the findSuccessors function has cycles, by walking from startNode.

        This method will hang if the given graph is infinite without cycle (the sequence of natural numbers for instance).

        Parameters:
        startNode - the node to start walking the graph.
        findSuccessors - The function to find successors of any given node. This function is expected to be deterministic and idempotent.
        Returns:
        an infinite stream of the nodes forming a detected cycle if there is any, or else Optional.empty().

      • newTreeWalker

        public static <T> Walker<T> newTreeWalker​(java.util.function.Function<? super T,​? extends java.util.stream.Stream<? extends T>> findChildren)
        Returns a Traversal object assuming tree structure (no cycles), using findChildren to find children of any given tree node.

        The returned object is idempotent, stateless and immutable as long as findChildren is idempotent, stateless and immutable.

        WARNING: the returned Walker can walk in cycles if findChildren turns out cyclic (like, any undirected graph).

        Parameters:
        findChildren - Function to get the child nodes for a given node. No children if empty stream or null is returned,

      • newGraphWalker

        public static <T> Walker<T> newGraphWalker​(java.util.function.Function<? super T,​? extends java.util.stream.Stream<? extends T>> findSuccessors)
        Returns a Traversal object assuming graph structure (with cycles), using findSuccessors to find successor nodes of any given graph node.

        The returned object remembers which nodes have been traversed, thus if you call for example preOrderFrom(T...) again, already visited nodes will be skipped. This is useful if you need to imperatively and dynamically decide which node to traverse. For example, the SHIELD and Avengers may need to collaborately raid a building from multiple entry points: 

        
 Walker<Room> walker = Walker.newGraphWalker(buildingMap);
 Stream<Room> shield = walker.preOrderFrom(roof);
 Stream<Room> avengers = walker.breadthFirstFrom(mainEntrance);

 // Now the two teams collaborate while raiding, no room is traversed twice...
 BiStream.zip(shield, avengers)
     .forEachOrdered((raidedByShield, raidedByAvengers) -> ...);
        In the normal case though, you'd likely always want to start clean, in which case, just recreate the Walker object.

        Because the Traversal object keeps memory of traversal history, the memory usage is linear to the number of traversed nodes.

        Parameters:
        findSuccessors - Function to get the successor nodes for a given node. No successor if empty stream or null is returned,

      • newWalker

        public static <T> Walker<T> newWalker​(java.util.function.Function<? super T,​? extends java.util.stream.Stream<? extends T>> findSuccessors,
                                      java.util.function.Predicate<? super T> tracker)
        Similar to newGraphWalker(Function), returns a Walker that can be used to traverse a graph of nodes. tracker is used to track every node being traversed. When Walker is about to traverse a node, tracker.test(node) will be called and the node will be skipped if false is returned.

        This is useful for custom node tracking. For example, the caller could use a TreeSet or some EquivalenceSet to compare nodes using custom equality or equivalence; or, use a java.util.ConcurrentHashMap if multiple threads need to walk the same graph concurrently and collaboratively: 

        
 Walker<Room> concurrentWalker =
     Walker.newWalker(buildingMap, ConcurrentHashMap.newKeySet()::add);

 // thread 1:
 Stream<Room> shield = concurrentWalker.preOrderFrom(roof);
 shield.forEachOrdered(room -> ...);

 // thread 2:
 Stream<Room> avengers = concurrentWalker.breadthFirstFrom(mainEntrance);
 avengers.forEachOrdered(room -> ...);

        In the case of walking a very large graph with more nodes than can fit in memory, it's conceivable to use Bloom filter to track visited nodes, as long as you are okay with probabilistically missing a fraction of the graph nodes due to Bloom filter's inherent false-positive rates. Because Bloom filters have zero false-negatives, it's guaranteed that the walker will never walk in cycles.

        Alternatively, instead of returning false, one can also throw an exception in the tracker for any already-traversed node, as a means to check that a data structure is a tree as opposed to a graph.

        Parameters:
        findSuccessors - Function to get the successor nodes for a given node. No successor if empty stream or null is returned,
        tracker - Tracks each node being visited during traversal. Returns false if the node should be skipped for traversal (for example because it has already been traversed). Despite being a Predicate, the tracker typically carries side-effects like storing the tracked node in a set (set::add will do).

      • preOrderFrom

        @SafeVarargs
public final java.util.stream.Stream<T> preOrderFrom​(T... startNodes)
        Starts from startNodes and walks depth first in pre-order by using findSuccessors function iteratively.

        The returned stream may be infinite if the graph has infinite depth or infinite breadth, or both. The stream can still be short-circuited to consume a limited number of nodes during traversal.

      • preOrderFrom

        public final java.util.stream.Stream<T> preOrderFrom​(java.lang.Iterable<? extends T> startNodes)
        Starts from startNodes and walks depth first in pre-order.

        The returned stream may be infinite if the graph has infinite depth or infinite breadth, or both. The stream can still be short-circuited to consume a limited number of nodes during traversal.

      • postOrderFrom

        @SafeVarargs
public final java.util.stream.Stream<T> postOrderFrom​(T... startNodes)
        Starts from startNodes and walks depth first in post-order.

        The returned stream may be infinite if the graph has infinite breadth. The stream can still be short-circuited to consume a limited number of nodes during traversal.

        The stream may result in infinite loop when it traversing through a node with infinite depth.

      • postOrderFrom

        public final java.util.stream.Stream<T> postOrderFrom​(java.lang.Iterable<? extends T> startNodes)
        Starts from startNodes and walks depth first in post-order.

        The returned stream may be infinite if the graph has infinite breadth. The stream can still be short-circuited to consume a limited number of nodes during traversal.

        The stream may result in infinite loop when it traversing through a node with infinite depth.

      • breadthFirstFrom

        @SafeVarargs
public final java.util.stream.Stream<T> breadthFirstFrom​(T... startNodes)
        Starts from startNodes and walks in breadth-first order.

        The returned stream may be infinite if the graph has infinite depth or infinite breadth, or both. The stream can still be short-circuited to consume a limited number of nodes during traversal.

      • breadthFirstFrom

        public final java.util.stream.Stream<T> breadthFirstFrom​(java.lang.Iterable<? extends T> startNodes)
        Starts from startNodes and walks in breadth-first order.

        The returned stream may be infinite if the graph has infinite depth or infinite breadth, or both. The stream can still be short-circuited to consume a limited number of nodes during traversal.
